description.plain:
Earl Simmons (December 18th, 1970 – April 9th, 2021), better known by his stage name DMX (an acronym for “Dark Man X”), was an American rapper and actor, mainly remembered for his success during the late ‘90s and the early 2000s, his raw and expressive style and his extravagant personality.

His stage name also paid tribute to the Oberheim DMX drum machine, an instrument he used when he made his own rap beats as a teenager.

His most successful works include his albums It’s Dark and Hell Is Hot and Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood (1998), as well as …And Then There Was X (1999); on the other hand, he also collected several hit singles, such as “Party Up (Up in Here),” “Ruff Ryders' Anthem,” “Where the Hood At?,” and “X Gon' Give It to Ya”.

As an actor, he also starred in the films Belly, Romeo Must Die, Exit Wounds, Cradle 2 The Grave and Last Hour: moreover, he hosted his own reality television series called Soul of a Man on the television network BET.

In many occasions, including his 2002 autobiographical book E.A.R.L.: The Autobiography of DMX, Simmons spoke openly about his addiction to crack cocaine, which began after his first mentor fooled him at the age of 14. On the other hand, he was also open about his Christian faith and how he used it to improve himself and his community.

At the start of April 2021, DMX was hospitalized and put on life support after suffering a heart attack. After several days in a comatose state, on the morning of April 9, 2021, Simmons was pronounced dead, according to an official statement released by his family. He was 50 years old.

On May 28, 2021, the rapper’s estate released his first posthumous album, Exodus, which he was working on at the time of his passing.

songs.full_title: X Gon' Give It to Ya by DMX
songs.title: X Gon’ Give It to Ya
songs.title_with_featured: X Gon' Give It to Ya

description.plain:
“X Gon' Give it to Ya” is the debut single from the Cradle 2 the Grave soundtrack—a 2003 action movie starring DMX and Jet Li.

In the song, DMX asserts his power, telling everyone to stay away from him and not pick a fight with him, or else he’ll “give it to ya!”

The song received renewed attention in 2015 after being featured in a trailer for Deadpool (eventually appearing in the movie itself, given ‘X’ also fits ‘X-Men’), and in the hit animated series Rick and Morty.

songs.full_title: What These Bitches Want by DMX (Ft. SisQó)
songs.title: What These Bitches Want

description.plain:
Released as the third single from …And Then There Was X, “What These Bitches Want” features R&B singer Sisqo. At the time of the song’s release, DMX was coming off of two number one albums, It’s Dark And Hell Is Hot and Flesh Of My Blood, Blood Of My Blood. Sisqo had recently released “Thong Song” which went on to become one of the biggest and most memorable songs of the year. The single art for “What These Bitches Want” features a picture of DMX with the lines, “The Biggest in Rap meets The Biggest in R&B.”



In the song, DMX raps about the various women in his life—the second verse is almost entirely dedicated to listing the names of women he has been involved with, matched with those classic DMX “what” shouts in the background.

songs.full_title: Ruff Ryders' Anthem by DMX
songs.title: Ruff Ryders’ Anthem

description.plain:
“Ruff Ryders' Anthem”, released as a B-side to “Slippin'”, was the fourth and final single from the album, and peaked at #93 on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1998. After DMX’s death on April 9, 2021, the song re-entered the Hot 100 and reached a new peak of #16, the week ending April 15, 2021. VH1 ranked it #79 on their list of greatest hip hop songs.

Producer Swizz Beatz provided some background information on the track in an interview with Complex:


I made the ‘Ruff Ryders Anthem’ beat in Atlanta. It was me just bugging out, having my New York influence and having my Atlanta influence. That track was the perfect blend which was awkward and different at the time because nobody had ever heard anything like that—including my clique.

DMX didn’t want to do it. He was like, ‘Man, that sounds like some rock ‘n’ roll track, I need some hip-hop shit. I’m not doing that. It’s not hood enough.’ I told him, ‘Yo, we can make it hood!’ […] Then he came in and did it and we were just hyping him up. The ‘What!’ ad-lib and all of that came about in the middle of us hyping him up. We left it in the track to add energy. Collectively, we came up with that vibe. It was his best shit at that time. Since then, X has trusted my judgment.


The background vocals and beat follow the rhythm of a military cadence. This reflects on the hook’s theme of being a cohesive unit.

songs.full_title: Party Up (Up In Here) by DMX
songs.title: Party Up (Up In Here)

description.plain:
A scathing diss track against unnamed rappers who were driving DMX out of his tree, this banger from …And Then There Was X is a common party song.

Producer Swizz Beatz talked about the track in an interview with Complex


That’s our biggest record, globally. ‘Party Up’ was at a time when things were moving fast. X was probably frustrated coming to the studio that day like, ‘Y’all gone make me lose my mind!’ A lot of the stuff we were doing was in the moment. When he says, ‘Y’all gone make me lose my mind!’ it’s probably what he was really feeling.

So we said, ‘You’re not the only person who feels like that. Everybody feels like that.’ We took that frustration and excitement and put it into a hit song. […] I just went in there bugging out. I didn’t think they would keep the ‘One, two, meet me outside.’


The music video shows DMX getting framed for a bank robbery and getting away after hoes invade the police siege.

songs.title: Slippin’

description.plain:
“Slippin'” is about self-motivation. In this song DMX shares his thoughts on making positive changes in his life.

DMX delivers powerful inspiration by vowing to himself to strive to become the person he wants to be.

A man who has hit rock bottom yet finds the courage from within to uplift himself and make his dreams.

songs.full_title: How’s It Goin’ Down (Album Version) by DMX (Ft. Faith Evans)
songs.title: How’s It Goin’ Down (Album Version)
songs.title_with_featured: How’s It Goin’ Down (Album Version) (Ft. Faith Evans)

description.plain:
”How’s It Going Down” is a 1998 DMX single featuring R&B star Faith Evans on the intro.

It tells the story of an affair he has with a woman who has kids—and the father is still around.  He questions whether the two seek the same type of relationship.

The girl’s jealous lover attacks a man he thinks is DMX, but it’s a case of mistaken identity.

Eventually, DMX gives up the whole affair, even though the sex is hot—he feels wrong about breaking up her family. It’s a pretty sweet ending to the story, from a man who says he’s ”not a nice person.”

songs.full_title: Damien by DMX
songs.title: Damien

description.plain:
“Damien” is a story, with characters voiced by DMX, highlighting the relationship between DMX and a character named Damien, with whom the rapper makes a deal which involves committing acts of violence in return for fortune and fame. It turns out that this “Damien” that DMX has been conversing with is, in fact, The Devil in disguise; luring DMX with fame and fortune as a rapper only to try to make DMX do things he doesn’t agree with, with Damien later trying to convince DMX to shoot one of his own friends. Think of it as a modern, rap version of Faust.

“Damien” is also the beginning of a trilogy (With The Omen and Damien III.

Fun Fact: The name Damien in context with the story is actually a reference to the horror classic “The Omen”, with Damien, spoiler alert, actually being the Anti-Christ.



(Damien from The Omen)

songs.full_title: We Don't Give a Fuck by DMX (Ft. Jadakiss & Styles P)
songs.title: We Don’t Give a Fuck
songs.title_with_featured: We Don't Give a Fuck (Ft. Jadakiss & Styles P)

description.plain:
“We Don’t Give a Fuck” finds X in familiar surroundings, collaborating with his fellow Yonkers MCs Jadakiss and Styles P of the LOX; all while over a dark and gritty Irv Gotti-produced beat.

On the track X is taking shots at an unnamed adversary who he feels crossed him. On a November 2017 episode of the “Drink Champs” podcast Irv Gotti revealed that DMX was attacking  Ja Rule after the Dog grew tired of musical comparisons to Rule as a result of Ja’s 1999 solo debut single “Holla Holla.”

Gotti’s timeline appears to be off because Flesh of my Flesh, Blood of my Blood was released in December 1998, while “Holla Holla” was officially released in March 1999. Despite it’s official release date, it’s very possible that “Holla, Holla” appeared on underground mixtapes several months leading up to Def Jam’s official release.

I made this record, I give X the beat… I’m in the studio as soon as I hear it I know he’s on the bullshit. he’s shittin' on Rule in that record.

Through the years the war of words progressed on songs like DMX’s “Do You” and “they Want War” as well as Rule’s “Blood In My Eye.”

The two old friends have since buried the hatchet.

songs.full_title: The Omen by DMX (Ft. Marilyn Manson)
songs.title: The Omen

description.plain:
The second of three Damien songs picks up after DMX is shot and Damien held him down while X was recovering. DMX heals then doesn’t want to have anything to do with Damien anymore. He tells Damien he don’t wanna roll with him anymore and that Damien’s ways aren’t his ways.

In the second verse X promises he ain’t fuckin' with Damien anymore. Then Damien tells X his cousin was killed by the police, so X feels compelled to work with Damien to solve his own problems. X gets his payback against the police who killed his cousin.

His conscience then tells him to lay low for a while. He tries to but Damien shows up to claim what is rightfully his, which is DMX soul that he sold him metaphorically in “Damien” off of It’s Dark and Hell is Hot X then calls for God to help him against Damien.

Producer Swizz Beatz talked about his approach in making the track:

I didn’t want to make the beat a street anthem, a club anthem, a story, or anything in particular. I wanted to leave it open so that Marilyn Manson had his space and so that X had his space. I left the negative space in there so that you could feel Marilyn Manson and X having their little crazy ass moment.

body.plain:
The second of three Damien songs picks up after DMX is shot and Damien held him down while X was recovering. DMX heals then doesn’t want to have anything to do with Damien anymore. He tells Damien he don’t wanna roll with him anymore and that Damien’s ways aren’t his ways.

In the second verse X promises he ain’t fuckin' with Damien anymore. Then Damien tells X his cousin was killed by the police, so X feels compelled to work with Damien to solve his own problems. X gets his payback against the police who killed his cousin.

His conscience then tells him to lay low for a while. He tries to but Damien shows up to claim what is rightfully his, which is DMX soul that he sold him metaphorically in “Damien” off of It’s Dark and Hell is Hot X then calls for God to help him against Damien.

Producer Swizz Beatz talked about his approach in making the track:

I didn’t want to make the beat a street anthem, a club anthem, a story, or anything in particular. I wanted to leave it open so that Marilyn Manson had his space and so that X had his space. I left the negative space in there so that you could feel Marilyn Manson and X having their little crazy ass moment.

songs.title_with_featured: Get At Me Dog (Ft. Sheek Louch)

description.plain:
DMX’s unbelievably popular first single “Get At Me Dog” scorched the eyebrows off of 1998 rap. The powerful beat, aggressive lyrics and accompanying video established DMX as a force to be reckoned with. He would go on to have 5 number 1 albums.

The song samples “Everything Good to You (Ain’t Always Good for You)” by B.T. Express.

This song shares instrumental similarity to Mase’s “Will They Die For You”, both of which were produced by Dame Grease.

They all came in and Jadakiss was like, ‘Oh man, that is crazy.’ Once one person co-signs it and they start writing to it, you’re locked in. songs.full_title: Look Thru My Eyes by DMX
songs.title: Look Thru My Eyes

description.plain:
In This song X takes you through the things he has seen in his life both in the streets and in the rap game.

He does this to show people what he has gone through, the way he has seen it, because it’s what he needs to do to stay alive. Both getting caught up with the street life and doing what’s necessary; and jumping into the rap game and killing his competition.

Ending the song with:

“And if you never met me, then you’ve no right to judge me
I’ve got a good heart but this heart can get ugly”

This brings home the point that he does what he has to do to survive in the game of life. And if you never met him and can’t understand him, then you shouldn’t judge him. Even coming off as threatening when saying his “[good] heart can get ugly”. Bringing the conflicting of the 2 sides of DMX to the forefront.

songs.full_title: Prayer (1998) by DMX
songs.title: Prayer (1998)

description.plain:
DMX takes a moment to offer a prayer to God.  Not only does he thank his creator, but he explains himself and even questions the motives of God.  This prayer was the beginning of a tradition that presumably will continue through all of DMX’s studio albums.



When asked, “What started [the prayer tracks]?” during an interview with Young Steff of 101.1 WIZF, DMX explained:

That’s a good question. Before I got signed, it seems like ‘95 or something like that, I got arrested. And everytime I go to jail I have a problem with the police, we get into it or whatever, [because] I don’t “perform” well. […] 23 hour lockdown, and you get nothin’ extra in your cell. So I’m in there, it’s freezing, got one little outfit, one sheet. But I had a pencil and a piece of paper. I remember waking up in the middle of the night, in tears, sweatin', and it’s like I saw these words and I wrote them down. I think it was because, like I said, it was cold in there – tears, sweatin'– it’s like, you don’t want to get out of the covers sweatin'. I’m fucked up, right? I got up anyway, and wrote it, in the middle of the night. They took [the paper] when I went to court the next day […] but I remembered it word for word. And that was my first prayer. And that’s what started it: because I was obedient, and because I realized the blessing that [God] gave me.

songs.full_title: Piece of My Heart by Conway the Machine
songs.title: Piece of My Heart

songs.lyrics:
I come to you hungry and tired, you give me food and let me sleep
I come to you weak, you give me strength, and that's deep
You call me a sheep and lead me to green pastures
Only askin' that I keep the focus in between the chapters
You give me the word and only ask that I interpret
And give me the eyes that I may recognize the serpent
You know I ain't perfect, but you'd like me to try
Unlike the Devil, who just wants me to lie 'til I die
Lord, why is it that I go through so much pain?
All I saw was black, all I felt was rain
I come to you because it's you who knows
You showed me that everything was black because my eyes were closed
You gave me the light and let me bask in your glory
So it was only right that, when you asked for this story
I put it together, to do our dogs some good
Our dogs being brothers and sisters in the hood
Plenty of times you sent help my way, but I hid
And I remember once, you held me close, but I slid
There was somethin' that I just had to see
That you wanted me to see so I could be what you wanted me to be
And I think I've seen it, 'cause I don't feel the same
Matter of fact, I know I've seen it, I can feel the change
And it's strange, almost got me beatin' down your door
But I've never known love like this before
It's a wonderful feelin' to get away from the pain
And up under the ceilin', I get away from the rain
And the strain that I feel when I'm here is gone
I know real, so I wipe away the tear, it's on
And I almost lost faith when you took my man
Monty, Paso, and Jay's brother Dan
And I fear that what I'm sayin' won't be heard until I'm gone
But it's all good, 'cause I really didn't expect to live long
So, if it takes for me to suffer for my brother to see the light
Give me pain till I die, but, please, Lord, treat him right

songs.full_title: Bath Salts by DMX (Ft. JAY-Z & Nas)
songs.title: Bath Salts

description.plain:
“Bath Salts” sees the late DMX unite with fellow New York hip-hop icons Nas and JAY-Z for a rowdy hood anthem.

The song was originally recorded for Nas' 2012 album Life is Good, but didn’t make the final cut. However, in 2017, during a beat battle between Swizz Beatz and Just Blaze hosted by the radio station HOT97, Swizz previewed a version of “Bath Salts” that featured JAY-Z, Jadakiss of The LOX and DMX.

Jada’s verse was eventually cut from thetrack for unknown reasons, although he appears elsewhere on Exodus, on the song “That’s My Dog”.

Plus, during an interview with GQ Swizz revealed that he originally planned to find a slot for the track on his 2018 solo album Poison, but then decided to wait:

I knew that track was special. I didn’t want to get hyped up because people wanted it [if I] didn’t have the right outlet or the reason to put it out. An X album is a better reason to put it out. I have many songs like that.

songs.full_title: Prayer II / Ready to Meet Him by DMX

songs.title_with_featured: Prayer II / Ready to Meet Him

description.plain: On “Ready to Meet Him,” DMX opens the song with a prayer. He then goes into his reasoning as to why he is ready to meet God. He expresses grievances with racism in America and problems within his community. In the end, DMX agrees to begin to live righteously in the eyes of God.

songs.full_title: Stop Being Greedy by DMX
songs.title: Stop Being Greedy

description.plain:
In this piece, DMX develops on the song “Damien” in a similar fashion. He represents two sides of him, one a typical man in the hood trying to make an honest life and get himself up from the darkness.  The other ego is what got himself into the dark, a bloodthirsty, horrible monster, controlled by the devil.
Both egos are done by DMX, one in a softer lighter voice and the dark one in his signature raspy growl.

songs.full_title: I Miss You by DMX (Ft. Faith Evans)
songs.title: I Miss You

description.plain:
A tribute to DMX’s grandmother, Mary Ella Holloway  after she passed away. X addresses how much he misses her and talks about his family members as if he’s talking directly to her in the afterlife.

The song features American singer Faith Evans singing Amazing Grace for the chorus. A very nice touch.

Official music video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zRYX441WERk

songs.full_title: The Convo by DMX
songs.title: The Convo

description.plain:
“The Convo” was labeled an “absolution poem” by Vibe Magazine… and rightfully so. The song is a reflection of what he’s done/doing, and he’s admitting to his wrongdoings in an attempt to connect with God.

The Vibe article also discusses how there’s a scar under DMX’s left eye as a result of getting jumped by 6 guys, leaving him with a broken jaw.



The incident took place a year before X released It’s Dark and Hell is Hot, and his jaw was still wired shut when recording the album. But that didn’t keep him from spittin' in the studio; ask Ja Rule.

songs.full_title: Get it on the Floor by DMX (Ft. Swizz Beatz)
songs.title: Get it on the Floor
songs.title_with_featured: Get it on the Floor (Ft. Swizz Beatz)

description.plain:
“Get It on the Floor” was the second single from DMX’s Grand Champ and finds him bringing the energy once again while being hyped up by producer Swizz Beatz, who spoke about the track with Complex:

I just wanted to get X back in the clubs with another mainstream record that people could relate to. I was like, ‘We should go back to the basics and get back in the club. We haven’t had nothing in the club for a while.’ I thought ‘Get It On The Floor’ was the perfect song for that time. It wasn’t ‘Party Up’ or ‘Ruff Ryders Anthem,’ but it still held a lot of weight. It was the best song for him and for us.

songs.full_title: Hood Blues by DMX (Ft. Benny The Butcher, Conway the Machine, Griselda & Westside Gunn)
songs.title: Hood Blues
songs.title_with_featured: Hood Blues (Ft. Benny The Butcher, Conway the Machine, Griselda & Westside Gunn)

description.plain:
On “Hood Blues,” DMX and members of Griselda take turns reflecting on their life and decisions. The song takes its name after its sample: Lee Mason’s 1971 track “Shady Blues.”

The song was initially teased by Darrin Dee Dean on Instagram on December 13, 2020, who posted a photo of the Griselda members together in an Atlanta studio. Benny The Butcher later shared a TikTok video of him and X listening to the song together in Miami.

songs.full_title: Letter to My Son (Call Your Father) by DMX (Ft. Brian King Joseph & Usher)

songs.title_with_featured: Letter to My Son (Call Your Father) (Ft. Brian King Joseph & Usher)

description.plain:
“Letter To My Son” featuring Usher and Brian King Joseph was one of the only two songs DMX announced for his comeback album before his untimely death on April 9, 2021, the other being “Skyscrapers”.

DMX described “Letter To My Son” as a piano and violin ballad. It’s a track dedicated to DMX’s  oldest son, Xavier Simmons.

description.plain:
This is the twelfth track on DMX’s debut album ‘It’s Dark and Hell is Hot’.

On this track, X tells a dark story about being a wanted man after committing a murder. The last verse of this song takes a twist as X ends up turning himself in – in a wild way.

songs.full_title: My Niggas by DMX
songs.title: My Niggas

description.plain:
Starting the track off with lines from his JAY-Z collaboration “Money, Cash, Hoes,” DMX goes into a track that, according to producer Swizz Beatz, was only intended to be a quick skit:

X used to always say, ‘My niggas.’ One day he was just humming and mumbling it in the studio. I had this weird beat for it. I remember it was only supposed to be a skit. He ended up going on longer than the skit and it became a song.

songs.full_title: ATF by DMX
songs.title: ATF

description.plain: Vividly explaining the struggles of the hood, DMX tells a dark story of a gangster struggling to get away from the ATF, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The song takes a whole new dimension in the last line, which, is actually identical to the first. Ultimately showing that the story was a dream but, that dream is about to turn into reality…

songs.full_title: Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood by DMX
songs.title: Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood
songs.title_with_featured: Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood

description.plain:
Produced by Swizz Beats. Released in 1998.

This song seems to be about DMX’s intense work ethic (He released two albums within the same year), and about how he is on top of his game and is killing his competition. As track 14, Flesh of My Flesh was also in the title of his second album released (Flesh of my Flesh, Blood of my Blood). This album, along with “It’s Dark and Hell is Hot” (His first album) both went platinum, were both released in the same year (1998) and are widely considered as “classics”

songs.full_title: Blood Red by DMX
songs.title: Blood Red

description.plain:
DMX’s latest single “Blood Red” was premiered at 9 a.m. EST on The Breakfast Club on June 28, 2016.

During his hour-long interview with DJ Envy, Angela Yee and Charlamagne Tha God, they spoke about Drake sampling “What These Bitches Want” and how Drake and Noah “40” Shebib reached out to X personally. They also touch on his transition to becoming a preacher one day, Puff Daddy’s criticisms of his voice, beef with Jay Z, his independent status, and much more.

https://youtu.be/x2zhU4m0Qug

On the topic of producer Divine Bars, who did this song as well as “Still Scratching” featuring Styles P, X talked about their chemistry.

He’s one of the unsigned hype type shit. People just don’t know. He got a lot of good music, and we’ve been friends for a long time.

“Blood Red” is available now on Apple Music and iTunes.

songs.full_title: Skyscrapers by DMX (Ft. Bono)
songs.title: Skyscrapers

description.plain:
The uplifting anthem “Skyscrapers” featuring Bono, from U2, was one of the only two songs DMX announced for his comeback album before his untimely death on April 9, 2021 – the other being “Letter To My Son” featuring Usher. X described “Skyscrapers” as having a “Miami feeling”.

Though DMX recorded his vocals for the track in 2020, Bono’s vocals and the track’s instrumental date back to at least 2012.

In 2019, an unreleased version of the song that featured two verses from Swizz Beatz and a guest verse from Kanye West surfaced. According to MTV, there’s also a version with Kanye on all three verses:

Swizz played the track for ‘Ye, whom he considers a brother, and got verbal confirmation from the Louis Vuitton Don that he would appear on the song. But after Kanye laid down his vocals and sent the track back, Swizz found that Yeezy had completed the entire song himself. “He gives me the track back, done, three verses, the chorus there and a bridge. So I’m like, there ain’t no room for me on that thing!” Swizz says laughing. “I’m like, 'Not on this one, baby.’ So I got two extra verses in the stash.”

description.plain: “Hold Me Down” is a beauty and the beast tag-team between the husky voice of X and the soft soothe of R&B icon Alicia Keys – the dynamic is very reminiscent of DMX’s early collaborations with the late superstar Aaliyah.

songs.full_title: Money Money Money by DMX (Ft. Moneybagg Yo)
songs.title: Money Money Money

description.plain:
“Money Money Money” sees DMX trade bars with Memphis' Moneybagg Yo – the youngest artist featured on Exodus – for the most contemporary sounding track on the album.

“Money Money Money” was originally set to feature a verse from the late rapper Pop Smoke. His contribution was replaced because Republic Records had already mixed those vocals onto the song “Deameanor”:

They used the Pop Smoke verse that we had. So that’s why we couldn’t use it on the album. So we just put Moneybagg Yo on it, because the song is called “Money, Money, Money,” and X wanted to have some of the younger energy as well. He didn’t want to just keep it so nostalgic, although that’s on there, too.

songs.full_title: Take Control by DMX (Ft. Snoop Dogg)
songs.title: Take Control

description.plain:
On “Take Control,” DMX and Snoop Dogg put their spin on the late Marvin Gaye’s 1982 R&B super hit “Sexual Healing”. X previously sampled Marvin Gaye on the 1998 track “Niggaz Done Started Something,” which flipped Marvin’s 1971 song “Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology)”.

Snoop and DMX previously collaborated on the 2012 track “Shit Don’t Change,” but just months before X’s passing, they went toe to toe in an electric Verzuz match that pulled in millions of viewers.

songs.full_title: Coming From by DMX (Ft. Mary J. Blige)
songs.title: Coming From

description.plain:
This is the seventh track off of DMX’s second album Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood.

This song touches on X’s past. He is reflecting on his life and how he turned out to be the person he is today.

The song also features a guest appearance from Grammy Award winning singer Mary J. Blige.

songs.full_title: Zombies by DMX (Ft. Jadakiss, JAY-Z, Nas & Swizz Beatz)
songs.title: Zombies
songs.title_with_featured: Zombies (Ft. Jadakiss, JAY-Z, Nas & Swizz Beatz)

description.plain:
“Zombies” is a rumored upcoming track from DMX’s as-yet-untitled eighth studio album. The track will feature fellow New York heavyweights Jay Z, Nas and Jadakiss.

Swizz Beatz played snippets of the track during his beat battle with Just Blaze on February 24, 2017. He seemed to confirm the track’s four participants when he retweeted a Busta Rhymes live-reaction gif. The DMX verse heard in the snippets is from his 2015 track “Spit That Shit.”

songs.full_title: They Want War (Ja Rule Diss) by DMX
songs.title: They Want War (Ja Rule Diss)

description.plain:
The “DMX vs Ja Rule” beef.

This beef is similar to the beef that was the most fatal of all, the 2pac and Biggie Smalls beef, in the way these two rappers are former friends, and were both, at one point, at the top of the rap game. But still the two artists seem to be cowering in the shadow that is 2pac and Biggies shadow over the rap game, even after their tragic deaths. The DMX vs Ja Rule beef began just after Irv Gotti signed both artists to Def Jam in the late ’90s. When their deep, growl-based vocals drew numerous comparisons, sparks quickly began to fly. DMX claims that Ja stole his style in which he delivers, a sort of gravely/growl raps, and Ja feels like D’s just hatin' beacause he’s a success and DMX aint yet.



In 2002 DMX released this freestyle on a Kay Slay mixtape the song titled, “They Want War”, is just a straight diss of Ja.

description.plain:
DMX communicating with God, admitting to his helplessness in wake of God’s mighty power and how he needs constant assistance to better himself as a servant and person.

X is generally known for his dark lyrics and use of profanity. It should be noted that X doesn’t swear once in the song as he shows the utmost reverence when talking with God.

songs.title_with_featured: Keep Your Head to the Sky

songs.lyrics:
I just wish we all understood... the beauty... of music

Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh, come on!)
Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh)

When I think I don't deserve it, I think about Jesus
And the fact that he was perfect and he thinks that I'm worth it
I know I got a purpose, so when I don't like what I see in the mirror
I learn to look past the surface
Believe me God heard this, 'cause these words came from my heart
I was in pain, it was dark
Then came the spark to light down the road
To let me know that he would lighten up my load
And it's gon' get greater, later
God only wants the best for me, but the devil's a hater
I can see his eyes through the smiles of fake friends
If y'all think hate wins... just keep waitin'
At the end of the day who's will will you think will prevail
Or will you live to tell
Miracle after miracle it comes through
The spiritual individual is in you

Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh, come on!)
Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh)

Lord if you hear me, You know that I'm comin' to You sincerely
I need You near me, please feel me
I'm sick and I need for You to heal me
I'm lost and lookin' for the real me, I'm tired and weary
Haven't been able to see things clearly
And even though I know You love me dearly, I still get leery
So where does that leave me? Lost and alone
I wanna call God but it's like I lost my phone
Every day is a struggle, 'cause I juggle my problems
Need to let go and let God, 'cause only he could solve 'em
I'm tired of lyin' to myself, thinkin' I could do it on my own
But when I get left alone
That's when the devil sneaks in and creeps in
Knocks on the door lightly then peeks in
And it's usually around the weekends
That I get reckless and jump off the deep end (Come on)

Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh, come on!)
Keep (Yeah!) your head (What!) to the sky (Uh, uh, uh, uh)

songs.full_title: Keep Your Shit the Hardest by DMX
songs.title: Keep Your Shit the Hardest

description.plain:
This is the sixth track on DMX’s second album Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Blood.

This track X goes off lyrically about multiple topics including his time in prison in the early ‘90s to street life.

songs.lyrics:
In the name of Jesus, let us pray
Father, please walk with us through the bad times, as well as the good
May we be heard and understood, from the suburbs to the hood
May you judge us by our hearts and not by our mistakes
And see that we get our breakthrough, however long that it takes
May you fill that void in our souls and lay our fears to rest
For there's no way we could live with Jesus, when we're living in the flesh
So I pray that you will allow our spirits to be born
Grow strong, move on, know right from wrong
First John, chapter two, versе fifteen
"Do not love the world or anything in the world," and wе know what that means
But listen
We know that distance we need to be away from fire to keep it missin'
But that doesn't mean we'll listen
Lord, you take care of fools and babies
You teach women to honor their men and men to respect their ladies
But lately, so many of us have gone astray
Doing wrong for so long that we've forgotten the way
Please, bring us back home
And instill in us the Word which is our backbone
We're just children that act grown
There is so much we're entitled to
Yet, we receive so little
Because this time in our spiritual warfare
We are comfortable in the middle
So I pray that you open our eyes
Give us the anointing to recognize the devil and his lies
If we keeps our actions wise, our prayers sincere
Our heads to the sky, you will diminish our fears
In Jesus' mighty name, we are brave, amen

songs.full_title: My Life by DMX (Ft. Chinky)
songs.title: My Life

description.plain:
The song ‘My Life’ by DMX is on the album “The Grand Champ” and it also featured on the movie “Never Die Alone” produced by himself soundtrack. In the song X, basically talks about his own life and his thoughts to change it.
If one pay attention to the structure of the whole song, it has a line of DMX and then a Chinky’s line (which is the same again and again), this type of structure is really common in DMX songs, “The Rain” for example.

songs.full_title: The Prayer V by DMX
songs.title: The Prayer V

description.plain: “The Prayer V” is the fifth track in a recurring series of tracks DMX has included on each of his albums. Counter to the previous Prayer tracks, DMX opted for the positive route with this one, listing nothing but positive results that he has been blessed with ‘by the grace of God’.

body.plain: “The Prayer V” is the fifth track in a recurring series of tracks DMX has included on each of his albums. Counter to the previous Prayer tracks, DMX opted for the positive route with this one, listing nothing but positive results that he has been blessed with ‘by the grace of God’.

songs.lyrics:
Let us pray
Father thank you for makin' me righteous and accepted through the blood of Jesus
Because of that I am blessed and highly favored by you
I am the object of your affection, your favors surround me as a shield
And the first thing that people come in contact with is my favor-shield
Thank you that I have favor with you and man today
All day long, people go out of their way to bless and to help me
I have favor with everyone that I deal with today
Doors that were once closed are now open for me
I receive preferential treatment and I have special priveledges
I am God's favorite child
No good thing will he withhold from me
Because of God's favor my enemies cannot triumph over me
I have supernatural increase in promotions
I declare restoration of everything that the devil has stolen from me
I have honor in the midst of my adversaries, and an increase of assets
Especially in real estate and an expansion of territory
Because I am highly favored by God I experience great victories
Supernatural turnarounds and miraculous breakthroughs; in the midst of great impossibilities
I receive recognition, prominence and honor
Petitions are granted to me even by ungodly authorities
Policies, rules, regulations and laws are changed and reversed on my behalf
I win battles that I don't even have to fight because God fights them for me
This is the day, the set time, the designated moment for me to experience the free favors of God
That profusely and lavishly abound on my behalf
In Jesus' mighty name we have prayed
Amen, and Amen

songs.lyrics:
In the name of Jesus
Let us pray
Father please walk with us through the bad times as well as the good
May we be heard and understood from the suburbs to the hood
May you judge us by our hearts and not by our mistakes
And see that we get a breakthrough however long that it takes
May you fill that void in our souls that will lay our fears to rest
Cause there is no way we can live for Jesus when we're liven in the flesh
So I pray that you allow our sprits to be born
Grow strong, move on, know right from wrong
First John, chapter two, verse 15
Do not love the world or anything in the world
And we know what that means, but listen
We know the distance we need to be away from fire to keep it missin
That doesn't mean we'll listen
Lord you take care of fools and babies
You teach women to honor their men and men respect their ladies
But lately so many of us have gone a stray
Doing wrong for so long that we've forgotten the way
Please bring us back home, instill in us the word which is our backbone
We're just children that act grown
There is so much that we're entitled to yet we receive so little
Cause in this time of spiritual warfare we're comfortable in the middle
So I pray that you open our eyes
Give us the annointing to recognize the devil and his lies
If we keep our actions wise and our prays sincere
Our heads to the sky you will demonist our fears
In Jesus' mighty name we have prayed
Amen and amen

songs.full_title: A Minute for Your Son by DMX
songs.title: A Minute for Your Son

description.plain:
This is the seventeenth and final track on DMX’s fourth album The Great Depression.

This track serves as a conversation with God (a topic that always appears on a DMX album).

This song is ironically called “A Minute for Your Son” because the whole track itself is actually 17 minutes long if you account for the hidden tracks attached to it on the album.

DMX speaking on his conversational / back-and-fourth with God tracks on each of his albums up until this point.
https://twitter.com/i/status/1380634599328346112

This is the seventeenth and final track on DMX’s fourth album The Great Depression.

This track serves as a conversation with God (a topic that always appears on a DMX album).

songs.full_title: More 2 a Song by DMX
songs.title: More 2 a Song

description.plain: This is the 11th track off of DMX’s highest selling album ‘And Then There Was X…’. The track touches on the state of rap at this point in time, particularly the subject matter throughout popular songs; money, clothes, and women. X believe’s there is more to life than that, thus it should be represented in the music.

songs.lyrics:
*BEEP* Thursday, June 28th, 2:02 AM
"I just called you and you said Domino's Pizza, but… and you said you were on your way, but there's just one problem
I'm all the way to fucking Rochester, New York. Wrong ho!"

Uhh, yo yo… yo, not this shit again
Dog gon' be a dog, y'knahmean? Motherfucking dog!
Don't get a dog if you can't take care of a dog
Gotta take care of the dog, y'know? Y'know?
Take it easy lady, y'know? Uh-huh
Give me a motherfucking break, will ya?

Shorty was the bomb, brownskin honey with a little dough
Come to find out she was a lil hoe, but still, yo
I pushed up, shorty had that ass like blaow
Had me scheming on how I could get that now
Was like girlfriend, let me drop a bug in yo' ear
She was mine cause I told her what she wanted to hear
Was like yeah, she knew how it was going down
She said page me, code zero, cause I know you get around
Didn't have a man, but even if she did dead
Cause my game is tight like a stocking cap on a nigga's head
I said, we'll get up like nine or somethin'
Don't act like when I say that ass is mine I'm frontin'
That night was right, she let me get that, hit that
Rip that, bounce it off the walls, flip that
But only, one thing went wrong, the rubber bust
But I didn't fuss cause, dog, shorty was the bomb

Shorty, UH! We only did it for that night
But man, the pussy was good
But shorty's fucking up my life, fucking up my life
Shorty, UH! We only did it for that night
But man, the pussy was good
But shorty's fucking up my life
C'mon, ma, give me a break!

A few days later, I hit her up just to keep it real
Was like, "Whassup, boo? How you been? How you feel?"
She said, "Aight, but my friend's kinda late
Today's the 13th, and it should've been here on the 8th"
I'm like, "For real?! Don't stress it, it'll come
It better cause I can't afford another little one"
She said, "Neither can I", I said, "Cool
Cause I got mad shit to do and you still going to school"
So at least we had the same thing in mind
Not to have this kid and everything would be fine
But I was blind to the fact that she was setting me up
For the kill, damn, why wasn't she on the pill?
And I still would check on her like once a week
Sometimes I hit it, sometimes I didn't, but shorty was a freak
And whenever I would speak on the baby
Shorty would be like, "I ain't having this kid, is you crazy?"


By now, wasn't looking too good
Cause she wasn't doing things that she told me she would
Like getting the price checked out for what we had to do
And it goes up another yard for every month after two
And a half, I had to laugh out of frustration
Now she's four months, I'm ready to hit the bus station
If I was still on that shit it would've made me rob her
Told her friends, "DMX? Yeah, that's my baby's father"
Her lil' stomach is shown, so now the heat is on
Maybe she'll see the light if I start to treat her wrong
Like if she thought that if she kept the baby she would keep me, so I played the game on her level, got sneaky
Let her have the kid, she said it was premature
Found out she was six months when she said she was four
So I left her with the pressure on the next man's arm
But she'll be aight, cause shorty was the bomb

songs.full_title: Already by DMX
songs.title: Already

description.plain:
Track 17 off DMX’s “Undisputed.”

[editors, add information here]

As far as the song’s concept goes, it can be described as a braggadocio as well as a possible diss towards unspecified rappers, or the industry in general.

The rhyming pattern in the verses here are relatively consistent with an each line followed by the anthemic shouting of “Already!” then with the proceeding line nearly always having 2 rhyming syllables connecting to the aforementioned previous line that preceded the “Already!”, then the next 2 lines having different rhymes schemes.

songs.full_title: The Born Loser by DMX
songs.title: The Born Loser

description.plain:
“Born Loser” is DMX’s first official single released in 1992/1993 after being signed by Columbia Records' Ruffhouse subsidiary. X is almost unrecognizable on this song, largely due to the smooth, almost LL Cool J-esque flow displayed on the song, and uncharacteristically lighter beat compared to his later recordings with Ruff Ryders.

Although the song is very autobiographical about X’s troubled early life prior to signing with Ruffhouse, it’s dark, sardonic humor, and funky beat almost makes him sound like the Fresh Prince, if Will Smith had a much darker sense of humor, and a rougher upbringing.

songs.title: When I’m Nothing

description.plain:
This is the ninth track on DMX’s fourth album ‘The Great Depression’.

On this track, X is taking a look at the people in his life. He’s asking if they’re around him because of his fame and celebrity or if they’re really down for him?

This song also features vocals from Grammy Award winning vocalist Stephanie Mills.

description.plain: Promoter Damon Feldman announced on February 5, 2014, Trayvon Martin’s birthday, that accused murderer George Zimmerman would face off against rapper DMX in a celebrity boxing match.

songs.embed_content: Read “On Fighting George Zimmerman” by DMX on Genius

annotatable.link_title: On Fighting George Zimmerman by DMX (Ft. The Game)
annotatable.title: On Fighting George Zimmerman

body.plain: Promoter Damon Feldman announced on February 5, 2014, Trayvon Martin’s birthday, that accused murderer George Zimmerman would face off against rapper DMX in a celebrity boxing match.

songs.lyrics:
DMX:" every black person who has been done wrong in the system.
"I am going to beat the living f**k out him … I am breaking every rule in boxing to make sure I f**k him right up. Once I am done with him, I am going to whip my d**k out and piss on him ... right in his muthaf**kin face. Zimmerman is a piece of s**t and that’s what he needs to drink."
GAME:If you could do it and it was legal, and there was no repercussions for knocking Zimmerman out, why not?

It's not really about that for me because, again, the Trayvon Martin story was sad enough. Justice needs to be served for his mother and his father and his family. I just think that how Zimmerman is playing it and being a media whore and looking for all this attention that he shouldn't be getting...If there's a chance to box him then I want in.

Man I believe I could knock Thor out.
All you need from Game is a YES. Draw it up and let's fight...I'll get in there and Zimmerman won't last three minutes.

songs.full_title: Sucka for Love by DMX (Ft. Dani Stevenson)
songs.title: Sucka for Love

description.plain: From DMX’s 2012 album, Undisputed. The album’s sixth track is an oxymoron of a love song. It’s about Darkman X’s ways expressing his feelings towards his shorties. X got seperated from his former wife Tashera Simmons in 2010, and has later for divorced. So now that DMX is a free man, he’s, to quote, “fuckin' all them bitches”.
